nodes.details: If the dataset uses some form of id, for example in the filename, this is generally used. Otherwise an appropriate id is generated, usually something like`pueblo04`
This is used if two versions of the title are given: in the original language, and a translation. The translation will typically be English.

This is roughly the place where the song originated. Most of the time, the place of collection is used as a proxy. However, it could be that a song was recorded elsewhere, and in that case the, say, birthplace of the performer might be used as the location instead.

nodes.description: geographic latitude coordinate of the location
geographic longitude coordinate of the location

nodes.details: This is required whenever location information is present.
nodes.description: whether the coordinates were automatically determined

nodes.details: If no lyrics are given, the language of the performer can be used.

nodes.description: culture or nationality of the original performer

nodes.details: The genres used are specific to a dataset.
Should have the same length as performers.
Can only be true if instrument_use is true
nodes.description: whether the piece uses percussive instruments
whether the piece uses the voice

nodes.details: Tonality in the broad sense. For Western pieces, this is usually the key.
The tempo of the song can be specified by a string (e.g. largo) or an integer representing the number of beats per second.

nodes.description: the meter of the song, e.g. 2/4

nodes.details: Date in a ISO8601-like format: 2020-02-16. However, often the month and day will be unknown, so these are also acceptable: `1824` for somewhere in 1824 and `1957-02` for somewhere in February 1957. Note that you cannot specify the day, unless you have specified the month and similarly, a month requires a year.
nodes.description: date when the song was collected

nodes.details: When the collection date is uncertain, this field specifies a a *lower* bound on the collection date. See the `date` field for details on the format
When the collection date is uncertain, this field specifies a an *upper* bound on the collection date. See the `date` field for details on the format
If a publication_key is known, the publication_title, publication_authors, publication_date, publication_type can be left empty.
The type of source: 'book', or 'CD', etc.

nodes.description: publication from which the song was encoded

nodes.details: Usually this is just the year of publication, but see `collection_date` for details of the date format.

If tune families are annotated, their ids are used. Alternatively, many folksong books contain multiple variants of the same melody, usually numbered as 1a, 1b, 1c, etc. These are considered tune families.
This is typically a link to a scan of the book, ideally even the right page number.
nodes.description: link to a preview of the source
name of person who digitized the song
date at which the song was digitized

nodes.details: These are usually people who contribute to a file after it has been encoded, by e.g. providing further metadata, converting the file, etc.
These are standard abbreviations for common licences, like CC-BY-SA 4.0; see licences.yml

nodes.description: path to the file relative to the dataset directory
a md5 checksum of the file
url to an online version of the file
an url to an online preview

nodes.details: Note that this concerns the file, not the piece itself.
nodes.description: whether the file contains the lyrics
whether the file has a licences
a JSON string with any other metadata

nodes.details: Warnings are comments so important that anyone working with the data should be aware of them.

nodes.description: a description or analysis of the song
